Recycling: Recycling can be a great way to reduce waste by reusing materials such as paper, plastic, and glass. Recycling programs can be implemented in communities to encourage residents to properly dispose of their waste.

Upcycling: Upcycling involves taking discarded items and giving them a new purpose. This can be done through DIY projects or by finding new uses for items that are no longer needed. For example, old pallets can be turned into planters or shelves.

Waste-to-energy: Waste-to-energy systems can convert waste into energy, such as electricity or heat. This can be done through various methods, including incineration, anaerobic digestion, or gasification.

Landfills: Properly managed landfills can be used to contain waste and prevent environmental damage. Modern landfills are designed to minimize leachate and methane emissions, and can be lined with layers of soil and other materials to prevent contamination.

Community composting programs: Community composting programs can be implemented in neighborhoods to encourage residents to compost their waste. These programs can provide resources and support to help residents get started with composting.
